item.title: The Stories That Shaped the Blockchain Narrative in 2015 - CoinDesk
item.description:
The Stories That Shaped the Blockchain Narrative in 2015 - CoinDesk

As counsel for Washington, DC law firm BuckleySandler LLP, Amy Davine Kim advises clients in the areas of US regulation of international business and financial services, with a focus on AML/BSA compliance and digital payments. Kim has been increasingly active in the digital currency space, recently working with North Carolina lawmakers to shape state regulation.

item.title: 4 Hype-Free Predictions for Private Blockchains in 2016 - CoinDesk
item.description:
4 Hype-Free Predictions for Private Blockchains in 2016 - CoinDesk

Preston Byrne is a co-founder and COO of Eris Industries and a fellow of the Adam Smith Institute. Previously, he was a securitisation and derivatives lawyer with Norton Rose Fulbright in London and he continues to "geek out" on high finance.

item.title: Visa Europe: The Blockchain is 'No Longer a Choice'
item.description:
Visa Europe: The Blockchain is 'No Longer a Choice'

Visa Europe highlighted the significance of bitcoin and the blockchain as part of a retrospective on the past year in payments this week, suggesting that traditional finance will soon adopt the technology. Entitled "Why 2015 was the year for payments", the blog post explores financial tech in a broad sense, while also touching on the subject of digital currencies.

item.title: Chain Issues Investor Shares on Nasdaq Blockchain Platform - CoinDesk
item.description:
Chain Issues Investor Shares on Nasdaq Blockchain Platform - CoinDesk

Blockchain startup Chain has issued shares to a private investor using Nasdaq's recently launched private markets blockchain solution, Linq. In statements, Nasdaq called Chain the first company to complete and document a private securities transaction with its Linq technology, a development the company and CEO Bob Greifeld termed a "major advance" for the blockchain industry.

item.title: PwC's 3 Predictions for Blockchain Tech in 2016 - CoinDesk
item.description:
PwC's 3 Predictions for Blockchain Tech in 2016 - CoinDesk

Jeremy Drane is practice leader of US FinTech, blockchain and smart contracts at 'big Four' professional services firm PriceWaterhouseCoopers (PwC), and Cathryn Marsh is leader of PwC FSI Institute, the company's division for new intelligence, perspective and analysis on trends affecting financial services.

item.title: Why I'm Predicting a $650 Bitcoin in 2016 - CoinDesk
item.description:
Why I'm Predicting a $650 Bitcoin in 2016 - CoinDesk

Richelle Ross is an independent cryptocurrency consultant and a computer science major at the University of Florida, whose interests include programming and cryptology. On 23rd July, I predicted on Quora that the price of bitcoin at the end of the year would rest around $420.

item.title: 5 Bitcoin and Blockchain Startups to Watch in 2016 - CoinDesk
item.description:
5 Bitcoin and Blockchain Startups to Watch in 2016 - CoinDesk

Jad Mubaslat is the founder and CEO of BitQuick.co, the Ohio State Bitcoin Group, a former graduate of Boost VC and a bitcoin user since 2011. BitQuick.co is a P2P marketplace that allows individuals to buy and sell bitcoins in the US via cash deposit.

item.title: 14 Headlines That Rocked Bitcoin and the Blockchain in 2015 - CoinDesk
item.description:
14 Headlines That Rocked Bitcoin and the Blockchain in 2015 - CoinDesk

It's been another formative year in the world of bitcoin and the blockchain, and while the price has been subdued over much of the year, other developments in the space have arguably been more intriguing than in any 12-month period previously.

item.title: Bitcoin's Big Challenge in 2016: Reaching 100 Million Users
item.description:
Bitcoin's Big Challenge in 2016: Reaching 100 Million Users

Michael Jackson is the former COO of Skype, a current venture capital investor at Mangrove Capital Partners and a board member at bitcoin wallet provider Blockchain. Here he explores the importance of creating bitcoin products and services that will delight users globally and prove the technology's worth in 2016.

item.title: Why did Bitcoin just jump in price (early June 2016)?
item.description:
Why did Bitcoin just jump in price (early June 2016)?

Answer: Bitcoin, the world's most popular digital currency, has been on a roll - but no one is really sure why. After dipping well below $200 in January, bitcoin trading at more than $410 Tuesday afternoon before cutting some of those gains, according to the CoinDesk Bitcoin Price Index. That's ...
